@cullenroche 2/ just think of a single corporate bond.  If nothing changes at all except real interest rates fall, what happens and why?  The bond price rises, despite no change at all to anything other than the real interest rate.

@cullenroche Huh?  No.  Future cash flows are simply worth more today if interest rates are lower.  No change in behavior necessary.  No change in fundamentals necessary.  It‚Äôs just that the present value of future cash flows is greater.
@cullenroche 4/ it‚Äôs the flip side of the waves of selling that trickle down from the fundamentally weakest equities into unrelated and sound assets.
@cullenroche 3/ yes this is an oversimplification, but captures the same basic dynamic that causes all assets to sell off together in a panic.

@cullenroche 2/ when you buy an asset from an investor, do they just sit on cash?  Usually not.  They deploy it into something else.  Buy up the treasuries, your force investors in IG debt.  Those investors buy it from others who are forced into junk.  Those sellers are forced into equity,

@cullenroche Mostly agree that it doesn‚Äôt improve economic fundamentals.  But when you lower the discount rate, the same future cash flows are worth more today, so equities rise (relative to where they would otherwise be.). And...there‚Äôs an even more direct effect.
@cullenroche That‚Äôs like saying that patients treated for gunshot wounds on the operating table don‚Äôt live longer than patients who didn‚Äôt get shot, so doctors have little effect.

@LMT978 Nope.  Definitionally if you're long a trend and the trend reverses, any signal to identify a trend reversal will necessarily miss the first datapoints of the turn (since those datapoints are necessary to the trend reversal signal).

@LMT978 Yes....and at the end of a trend, following it is disastrous.  By the time the trend is actually broken, you've taken quite substantial losses as a trend follower.  Whether those are made up for by the trend following wins depends on the asset's serial autocorrelation.
@codetsunami That feels unlikely to me given sentiment and ecosystem growth (but anything is possible).  That might be the right model for altcoins currently.

2/ lots throughout the crypto world betting on and excited by bullish news.  That suggests we're out of the "wall of worry" earliest stages of a bull run and into the main body of the trend.

9/ I write all this based on the data currently available, and in light of the public policies currently being discussed as viable.  If I get new data, my opinion may change.  At least now I feel like I have enough data to *have* an opinion.
8/ these costs might be tolerable if we had reason to believe it would in total, meaningfully save lives.  I think current evidence suggests the opposite.

7/ it‚Äôs also worth noting that aside from simple mortality, ‚Äútrack and trace‚Äù creates many social and political problems ranging from loss of civil liberties to furthering disparate health and economic outcomes among privileged and less privileged communities.

6/ to be clear - re-opening the US *will* result in faster covid19 deaths, and maybe more total covid19 deaths.  But we have no reason to believe it will change the total dramatically since containment seems clearly impossible. And quarantining causes a great many indirect deaths

5/ with that said, ‚Äúflattening the curve‚Äù remains prudent.  We still very much want to avoid our health systems getting overwhelmed.  Current evidence suggests this doesn‚Äôt require the level of quarantining we‚Äôre currently doing in most areas of the US.

4/ the best case would be to successfully contain it.  If we can‚Äôt though, trying to with ‚Äúshelter in place‚Äù is the *worst* choice.  We‚Äôll still end up with most people getting infected but we‚Äôll also cause much greater economic (and indirect health) harm.

@benjmnr I actually find Twitter super useful for this process - I can very quickly expose an expert opinion to contrasting views from many different types of experts and thinkers.

10/ Many doctors accepted on scant evidence that consuming lots of dietary cholesterol led to high blood serum cholesterol which is linked (although causality still not totally clear imo) to heart disease.  Eating cholesterol -> high blood cholesterol.  Intuitive but wrong.

9/ One example of where this process originally failed (and I had to add the possibility that an entire field may be led astray) is in nutrition.  40 years ago, the vast majority of doctors and medical experts of all types recommended high carbohydrate, low saturated fat diets.

8/ One key premise here is my belief that it's not productive to try to become an expert in all things relevant to you.  That's not possible, and often leads to comical false confidence.  E.g. "do your own research" can quickly become, "I read WebMD and know more than doctors."

7/ When the bias/incentive-adjusted expert opinion fails to yield a consensus, I usually just think of the question as currently unanswered or unanswerable.  If it's very high value, I may keep digging and try to become an expert myself, but usually accept that it's "unknown."

6/ E.  What we're left with is a kind of bias/incentive-adjusted weighted opinion from relevant experts.  When this provides an overwhelming consensus, it's usually worth accepting.  Last question is if there's something structural that may lead the entire field of experts astray
5/ D. Take a rough poll of both a. opinion and b. confidence, among relevant experts.  Ask experts why other experts who disagree with them are wrong.  This helps further expose biases/incentives.

4/ C. Identify incentives/biases.  i.e. economists advising politicians are generally biased to tell politicians what they want to hear (print money).  Doctors hired by Big Tobacco end up finding that smoking is harmless.

3/  B. identify relevant metrics of "expertise" relevant to the question we're answering.  Do we look for economists running a top college department or advising countries or advising banks?  Identify key 'political' schools of thought among those experts.
2/ A. identify experts' actual area of expertise.  I.e. a doctor is not an expert on public health policy.  A political science academic is not an expert on running a successful campaign.

I spend much of my time navigating contrasting expert opinion and trying to adjust for biases, and to identify when expert consensus may be simply wrong.  Here's the heuristics I use.  What do you suggest for improvement? -

@Beastlyorion You're right.  These long threads start as a rough idea that I then write as a stream of consciousness.  I have no idea how long they'll be when I start (-:  I'll turn this into a medium essay and post it.

26/ I think we're likely to see a simultaneous increase in dollar usage globally, *and* a piling into (on much smaller scale) alternative currencies that defend against that surveillance, that loss of control (by both individuals and governments.)

25/ and globally - think about this - if your country is "dollarizing" and you're increasingly exposed to the vagaries of the white house and the US fed, to surveillance by US institutions, how do you think about hedging that?

24/ As this possibility becomes tangible to US investors for the first in more than a generation, we're likely to see more debt linked to inflation rates, long-term salary contracts that adjust for inflation, and a shift in portfolios towards inflation hedges.

23/ In places like Argentina (let alone Venezuela), the average citizen thinks about inflation frequently.  They consider the risk of a sharp increase inflation as they decide how to invest, how to save, where to work.

22/ Some specific examples - many banks are publishing general sell side research suggesting that investors may want to allocate 2-10% of their portfolio to gold and digital assets "just in case" inflation becomes a serious near-term threat.

21/ while deflation may be the greater concern, the primary expectation, or even the eventual outcome, for the first time in 30 years, savvy US investors are serious about hedging inflation.  The uncertainty has dramatically increased.
@ashishgyan @threadreaderapp premature (-:

20/ even as the world desperately clamors to get a hold of dollars and as US consumers may increase their savings rate relative to consumption, and as financial leverage decreases, I think the "skew" around inflation expectations is increasing - I'll clarify -

19/ can we get *both* dollarization and inflation for dollar users?  I think it's quite likely (but I say that humbly - this is immensely complex, novel from many angles, and there's also uncertainty around policy and psychology).

18/ and political and economic concerns around many countries means their currencies are viewed as more volatile, less trustworthy.  For example, if investors fear that the euro may fail in the next few years, even Europeans may favor buying debt and doing trade in dollars.

17/ the "new" story is global dollarization which @RaoulGMI articulates well.  A great deal of global trade (even between countries in the eastern hemisphere) is denominated in, and literally uses, USD.  Less financial leverage means more demand for raw USD.

16/ One thing in common with 2008 though and deflationary is the unwinding of debt.  Mortgage debt, corporate loans to the oil and gas industry and many other types of debt are suddenly far riskier.  Financial leverage is decreasing, that's kind of like a reduction in velocity.

15/ and unlike in 2008, more of the newly printed money is going into the hands of consumers who are likely to spend it.  Money to a big company may just sit on their balance sheet in a bank account.  Money to a struggling family or small business gets spent, and quickly.

14/ but we also have less demand for stuff.  People have less reason to drive or fly, so less demand for gasoline and jet fuel (both synthesized from crude oil).  And if people are worried about their financial future, they save more and consume less.

13/ which brings us to today.  The world is making less stuff, and at least for a few years, we're likely to have a downward drag (all else equal) on productivity from protectionism/ tariffs, and health concerns around covid19.

12/ but if banks are required by regulation or strongly incentivized by governments to just keep the money idle, it's not demanding to buy stuff.  And if people don't expect inflation, they don't bid up wages or goods at the margin.

11/ At this point, let's take a step back and try to synthesize this a bit.  MV=PQ says there's a certain amount of money around that wants to buy a certain amount of stuff.  More money or less stuff, and prices (P) have to go up.

10/ came along and said:  basically unlimited.  Or at least it's such a large amount, you don't need to worry about it.  And if we print that money and use it productively, productivity will increase, further allowing us to print more money.

9/ money printing is pretty sweet for governments and politicians of all stripes.  In the short-term, it feels like a "free lunch."  How much money could be printed without causing inflation?  People stopped guessing in the last decade.  Then Modern Monetary Theory (MMT),

8/ another angle was around inflation *expectations.*  The idea here was that inflation is less about money printing and more about investor expectations for future inflation.  Kind of made sense for financial assets like bonds and maybe wages, not so much for prices of goods.

7/ This wasn't about velocity in the normal economic sense as being market driven - this argument's specific depended on regulation.  For example, the ECB lent money to European central banks and required them to then buy sovereign debt with much of it: extremely low velocity.

6/ then it became more subtle.  The more nuanced idea: we weren't getting inflation because a lot of the newly printed money was just sitting back at the Fed or in banks as deposits.  Banks were reluctant to loan it out.  Demand for loans was also relatively weak.

5/ at first - the story was about velocity.  The argument was, "sure we printed tons of money, but velocity of money collapsed, so the actual amount of money circulating didn't rise much."  But this framing didn't offer much predictive power and lacked specificity.

4/ we already had some contradictory data: Japan had been printing tons of money for more than a decade but were still stuck in a deflationary trap.  Most investors seemed to view Japan as kind of an exception without a clear view on why.

3/ Within that framework, the money printing and quantitative easing that followed the 2008 financial crisis should have produced severe inflation.  Alan Greenspan in 2009 predicted massive inflation imminently for example.

2/ First a little background.  Prior to 2008, a massive increase in M1 (money supply), and then quantitative easing, most investors and economists thought that the simplified MV=PQ model was at least very roughly reasonable as a starting point.

A very complicated topic being debated even by the most senior economists and seasoned investors: what does the world look like as we combine deflationary "dollarization" with massive money printing.  This thread is an attempt at exploring the subject -

7/ and...we usually don‚Äôt *know* these probabilities, we can only guesstimate them.  That brings in the issue of confidence intervals, something even less natural, harder to develop an intuition for.

6/ humans didn‚Äôt evolve to process small probabilities.  It takes a lot of practice to get good at interpreting them in context, to make intelligent decisions around them.  I don‚Äôt think anyone is really a natural at this.

5/ but also easy to go in the opposite direction.  To worry about extremely unlikely risks.  In the US terrorism has killed a tiny, tiny fraction of those killed by gun homicides, car accidents, or diabetes.  But when terrorism is in the news, we tend to fear it far more.

4/ does it make sense to spend $10 million a year as a country to avoid a 1% risk of 10 million deaths?  How about $10 billion?  Politically it‚Äôs hard to justify spending a lot of money on an event that we haven‚Äôt seen recently.  Easy to convince the public its wasteful.

3/ expert opinions (and those of pundits too) are typically turned into binaries: this will happen or it won‚Äôt.  That‚Äôs disastrous since so much of life is asymmetric.  Basic statistics is a cornerstone of intelligent discourse on almost anything concerning public policy.

8/ I now get to navigate this challenging industry with the strongest team we've ever had - a thanks to my colleagues at BlockTower.  Couldn't survive the whirlwind without you.

7/ I still occasionally feel giddy with excitement that I get to visit the garage where the future Steve Jobs and Bill Gates are inventing the future.  And current events remind me why I'm in this industry, more strongly than ever.

6/ the tribalism and in-fighting, the egos, the operational challenges.  All challenging in ways that were occasionally disheartening.  But my basic belief in the industry was never shaken.  We're at the center of a technological and social revolution.

5/ as an industry, we want to (and are) changing the world, but that means executing on the details and dealing with the day to day challenges of any industry.  Decentralization often means lack of coordination.  Brilliant and hungry youthful energy often comes with naivete.

4/ fairly quickly the shiny gloss wore off.  My idols were brilliant in specific ways, but all were human, fallible, sometimes petty or narrow minded.  Running BlockTower was challenging for all the typical start up reasons - HR, management, etc.

3/ 2017 was an incredible time.  I got to meet many of my "idols" and felt insanely lucky to almost immediately be treated as a colleague in an industry in which I lacked technical expertise or experience.  It was also a crazy time with rampant scams and "accidental scams."

2/ and having relatives to had to flee Nazi germany (some successfully, others not), the idea of a censorship and seizure resistant asset made intuitive sense.  But...it took me many years to really grok bitcoin and how PoW provided probabilistic finality and decentralization.

This thread is a reflection on 3 years in crypto as a 'professional' in the industry and a community member.  (I invested back in 2014, but didn't really participate otherwise until early 2017).  I was "looking" for bitcoin since 2008 when fed bailouts made me seek a fiat hedge.

5/ I still wouldn't recommend that you try to get "fancy", but panics and extreme bubbles are basically the only time I think a non-full time professional should ever do anything more than buy and hold equity or credit with rare rebalancing.

4/ and during panics - it's wall st that becomes a forced seller.  The same "smart money" that is putting on some arbitrage spread or buying credit today, may be forced to sell it at much worse prices in 2 weeks.

3/ during panics - it's a very rare occasion when retail can beat wall st.  That's because Wall St (professionals) are under immense structural pressure to be early.  To arbitrage spreads tightly, to be aggressively structurally long, etc.

2/ my view on markets is that if you're not trading something full time, professionally, you're better off not trading.  Just buy and hold and consider repositioning or rebalancing only after extreme moves.

8/ happen adverse to the "crowded" trades.  Last night, being long on bitmex and short elsewhere became the crowded trade.  Really nimble and sharp traders can profit from these dislocations, but at the very least, being aware of how extreme things can get can prevent losses.

7/ It's very hard to accurately anticipate these things specifically, but you can certainly be aware of them and avoid being caught on the wrong side of structural problems.  When markets are going crazy - these types of dislocations always happen - and always

6/ My point in all this is that the market action from $3600-$4600 was basically entirely driven by market microstructure dynamics, having nothing to do with where people actually wanted to buy or sell BTC.  This is happening in traditional markets too btw, right now.

5/ This fear of an unlimited spread prevented more arbitrageurs and traders from taking the other side of liquidations on Bitmex.  Some people also had challenges transferring BTC there as many wallets and exchange withdrawals were delayed due to insufficient tx fees.

4/ but as the spread widened, everyone had to worry about liquidations.  What if BTC stayed at $4k on Coinbase for example, but liquidations continued on Bitmex for another hour and took us down to $1500 there?  Lots of people with "hedged" positions had to fear liquidations.

3/ the cascading liquidations on bitmex created an increasing spread between bitmex and spot prices.  At first - arbitrageurs and traders like us deliberately or "accidentally" accumulated positions on bitmex (with an incredible negative funding rate paying us to do so).

2/ Once BTC broke below $4800, everything was totally dominated by cascading liquidations on bitmex in particular, and through crypto (both exchanges and credit desks) more generally.  It kind of became its own monster.  I don't know anyone who *chose* to sell at, say, $4100.

@Satoshis_D 6/ would be something like, "the model places 80% of the predictive weight on factors A and B (which the model itself creates), and those factors are heavily bullish now, so the model wants to buy.  So...I'm buying.

@Satoshis_D 5/ you can calculate the present value of a factor using current market data, and then you run those factors through the statistical approach to get a "prediction."  But if you said, "*why* is the model telling you to buy now"?  The best answer I could give

@Satoshis_D 4/ but the output of the model often can't be meaningfully interpreted.  For example, PCA might say, "US equities are 'explained' by these 100 factors that this model just invented.  Those factors, we'll call them A, B, C, D, etc, don't match anything in the world.

@Satoshis_D 3/ but it explains and predicts the market behavior using a set of factors that have no real world meaning.  I've done PCA myself (both by hand and with code) and understand what's happening in the most basic mechanical sense,

@Satoshis_D 2/ this can even happen without using an algorithm at all.  For example, "principal component analysis" is statistical approach that creates a new set of factors to explain and predict how, say, the stock market will behave.

@Satoshis_D Some algos do what their programmer intended.  But there's lots of algos for which their programmers literally have no idea how they work.  They're "black box."  They use such complicated methodology that humans can't follow it at all.

8/ TLDR: *every system in our lives* is determined by "just people."  Yet, we can rationally have confidence that the constitution won't be radically changed tomorrow.  Friction and incentives are *powerful* and can be "trusted" as much as anything in life outside of physics.

7/ And we see how meaningful these things are in practice.  Your town's local ordinances probably get changed every year.  We haven't had a constitutional amendment since 1992, and the last one before that was 1971.

6/ we can even think of the psychology/culture as a framing for incentives and further simplify.  All that matters is: the difficulty in coordinating a change, and the incentives for stakeholders to support that change.

5/ C: incentives - politicians are wary of promoting a change to the constitution given point B above, so these conversations barely even get started.  Even suggesting a change is likely to be punished by voters.

4/ B: psychological/cultural - Americans value the 'immutability' of the constitution today.  That wasn't always the case, but it is now.  Most Americans start from the position that "no change" is the default position.

3/ why do we have confidence that the constitution won't be radically changed tomorrow?  Why is it easier to rewrite local ordinances than the constitution?  3 reasons:  A. Structural - it's high friction to change the constitution, supermajorities and a slow process.

2/ First - everything in life is either determined by people, or by physical laws (or some mix).  Our systems of law, business, military, religion - any and all institutions - it's all just social consensus.  Yet, there's great differentiation in how readily those systems change.

"There's nothing stopping people from changing the bitcoin supply cap!"  "There's nothing stopping people from changing the constitution so only cats can vote!"  Let me suggest a more nuanced mental model for thinking about how resistant to change a human system is.

4/ of course...many (destined to fail) traders don't learn this lesson.  They either remain foolhardy, or become too timid.  But quick learners only need to "blow up" once or twice early in their careers to decently calibrate.

3/ the "blow up" for a junior trader might be huge for the size of their book, but trivial at the firm level.  At its core a "blow up" just means the trader losing more than they thought possible in a way that shocks them into being more thoughtful going forward.

2/ trading firms historically let this happen with "training wheels" on.  Many trading firms are structured with a bunch of brilliant young traders doing their thing fairly independently, and then senior traders acting as risk managers.

Almost all traders "blow up" at some point in their careers, including the great traders.  This seems almost necessary.  "Blow up" doesn't have to mean giant monetary losses, it just needs to be psychological shock that causes a long-term realization of fallibility.

8/ the two most prolific educators on this topic (and figures I admire greatly overall) were Carl Sagan and magician/debunker James Randi.

6/ it's reasonable to call this claim debunked if we understand how flashlights work and can explain the same effect with a simple consumer product rather than assuming I have superpowers.  The burden is on me to provide some evidence that can't be so easily explained.

5/ is to view such claims as debunked if any evidence put forth to support it can be explained in simpler ways.  One last example: I claim to have a superpower to cause any object to emit a bright light.  I demonstrate this by shining a flashlight.

4/ most conspiracy theories and pseudoscience are like claiming I have a dragon in my garage.  It's a "moving target" to disprove it, since I can always add on to my claim to dodge your tests.  A reasonable heuristic (the only reasonable one imo),

3/ you reach out to touch the space where I claim the dragon stands and feel nothing.  "It's incorporeal" I say.  For any test or experiment you devise, I can find an answer that makes it impossible to disprove the existence of my dragon.

2/ Sagan used this example: I claim there's a dragon in my garage.  You come visit and point out you don't see anything.  "It's invisible" I say.  You use an infared scope and still see nothing.  "It's exactly the temperature of the air" I say.

11/ these were just some really simple thoughts addressing some common misconceptions or questions I‚Äôve been seeing.
10/ this is a tricky and nuanced challenge, but with no insurmountable challenges, just a lot of nuanced decisions that have to be made, and likely some failures along the way.

9/ we already have light forms of the web of trust.  Keybase for example let‚Äôs you link accounts like Facebook and twitter to a private key.  Facebook does some light verification.  We build up online reputations over time.  What makes you think this twitter account is ‚Äúmine‚Äù?

8/ the hard part in all this is how you connect a private key to a person in a persistent way.  This could be done with centralized assistance (eg trusted authorities that verify a person including with things like passports) or via a decentralized ‚Äúweb of trust.‚Äù
7/ loans can be collateralized with digital assets that can be taken from a smart contract, or they can be uncollateralized and enforced by a ding to a decentralized credit score.
6/ the decentralized equivalents run in parallel.  A private key signature is like a passport - loans aren‚Äôt made to addresses, they‚Äôre made to identities.  The address is just a representation.
5/ we use things like passports to prove our identity and link a person to a credit score to a loan.
4/ for the average American, when they default on a loan, they have negative net worth.  They‚Äôre judgement proof.  The only enforcement is a lowered credit score.

3/ loans are typically collateralized by specific assets (eg mortgages) or by a person or company‚Äôs total assets (eg credit cards).  Collection requires bringing a series of civil suits.  If someone has no assets, you can‚Äôt collect.  They‚Äôre ‚Äújudgement proof.‚Äù
2/ most of defi requires decentralized identity.  Most of what we call defi today is centralized.  First, let‚Äôs quickly go over how loans work in the centralized traditional system.
Really superficial thoughts on decentralized identity - an ‚Äúeasy‚Äù problem that might take a decade to really solve.
